Dear families,

I cannot begin to imagine the emotions we each feel in this moment (or those leading to this time), but what I can do is confirm our commitment to you and the ideals we strive for as a school community. We cannot remain silent. As a school community, we are here for each other, and more than ever we need to reach out to our friends and neighbors and show the compassion, empathy, and humanity everyone deserves.

I should be clear that hatred and racism have no home at our school. Bigotry, bullying, or discrimination will not be tolerated. We treasure and hold dear the relationships that create our unique community -- those between teacher, student, and parent, all to support students’ academic and personal growth.

Sincerely,
Sandy Beery

Meet High School Social Studies teacher, David Neuman!
🍎 He says, "I love working with our students and families to achieve their educational goals. My favorite class to teach is World History because I get to show students how their world came to be what it is today, and how events and social movements relate to each other to form cultures and societies."

🎁 The best gift he's been given is the ability to be a teacher. He does his best to help his students learn practical life lessons and skills that will benefit them for the rest of their lives.

🧡 He also thinks that being friendly and courteous with others is an important key to getting along with people we don't know. After all, strangers are friends we haven't met yet.

▫️ Extend learning that supports their academic interests through engaging projects and presentations.
▫️ Connect with students from across the country and the world.
▫️ Make new friends.
▫️ Develop leadership skills.
▫️ Gain social confidence.
▫️ Explore new interests and expand their knowledge.
▫️ Share their own original creations with peers.

▫️ Have fun!

One of the main reasons I am interested in science is because in the future I want to work as a forensic scientist."
